[home](/ "Home") » [about us](/about-us/ "About Us") » [public services](/about-us/public-services/ "Public Services") » inmate copy service

Inmate Copy Service

Through our Inmate Copy Service, we aim to provide Texas inmates whose court records are held by the Texas Supreme Court, the Court of Criminal Appeals, or the 3rd Court of Appeals (criminal records only) with copies of their trial records at a reasonable cost.

expand all collapse all

Court Records 

What court records can I access through the Inmate Copy Service? 

We can provide copies of court records held by:

  * the 
  * the 
  * the (criminal records only).



Which court records are stored at the library?

None. The library does not store case files and does not have access to the records of any other courts. Our library is authorized to temporarily borrow court records from the courts listed above.

If your case file is not currently stored or on appeal at one of these courts, you should contact the clerk at the original trial court or the appropriate court of appeal. For help locating records from other courts, please see the library's guide.

Can I access exhibit files through the Inmate Copy Service?

No. The library does not have the authorization to copy exhibit files from the 3rd Court of Appeals and the Court of Criminal Appeals.

In order to obtain copies of exhibits from these courts, you will need to contact the court directly to file a motion requesting these documents. We cannot facilitate or assist you with this process. You may also contact your trial court directly to obtain copies of exhibits.

Library Materials 

Can I access other library materials?

We can also provide photocopies of state and federal statutes, codes, rules and regulations, excerpts from select library materials, and case law that is not listed as available at a TDCJ unit library in the ( en español). Note that specific citations are required and handwritten letters must be legible for any request to be completed. See fees, pricing, and payment information below.

Can you provide legal advice or help with my case?

No. The library will not provide any legal advice or interpret any statutes, codes, laws, rules, regulations, case law, or other legal texts.

Inmates should consult with their attorney if they require assistance. If they do not have an attorney, the office of the may be of assistance. Information on how to contact the is available in the ( en español).

Placing an Order 

How do I order court records? 

To obtain copies of records for an inmate, send a request for specific court documents to:

Inmate Copy ServiceState Law LibraryP.O. Box 12367Austin, TX 78711-12367

You can also make a request through our [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian") service. Please submit the following information:

  * Full name and any aliases
  * Date of conviction
  * County of conviction
  * Appeal number
  * Complete mailing address



The information submitted must be legible and as complete as possible or fulfillment of your request will be unnecessarily delayed.

How long does the process take? 

Processing time may take 2 to 4 weeks depending on the nature of the request.

Once we obtain the court records, we will send you an estimate detailing the total number of pages and total cost for photocopying. Photocopies will be mailed to you as soon as we receive payment. **Do not submit payment until you have received an estimate.**

What formats are available? 

We can provide copies in print or via a digital file added to a USB drive or uploaded online. Please contact us for more information about obtaining copy requests digitally.

Fees & Payment 

How much does it cost?

Charges for obtaining physical photocopies are as follows:

  * 25 cents per page
  * 8.25% state sales tax
  * service charge (a flat rate of $5 for most orders but this increases depending on the total number of pages copied)
  * postage (if applicable)



Charges for digital copies are as follows:

  * $5 flat fee per court file
  * $6 USB drive (if applicable)
  * 8.25% sales tax
  * postage charges (if applicable)



How do I pay for copies?

Once you receive the estimate, you can make a payment in person, over the phone, or by mailing us a check or money order.

The library accepts Visa, MasterCard, Discover, and American Express.

We also accept cashier's checks, money orders, personal checks, and inmate trust fund checks. Payments should be made payable to _State Law Library_ and mailed to:

Document DeliveryState Law LibraryP.O. Box 12367Austin, TX 78711-12367

The library is unable to provide free copies to inmates who are indigent.

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:49 PM

**How are we doing? !**

Mailing List

Sign Up

Thanks for signing up!

You can unsubscribe at any time using the Unsubscribe link at the bottom of every email.

Email

Email Lists

Library Database Trainings

Library Newsletter

Operation timed out, please try again.

By submitting this form, you are consenting to receive library marketing emails from: Texas State Law Library, 205 West 14th Street, Room G01, Austin, TX, 78701-1614, US, https://www.sll.texas.gov. You can revoke your consent to receive emails at any time by using the SafeUnsubscribe® link, found at the bottom of every email. [Our Privacy Policy.](https://www.sll.texas.gov/about-us/library-policies/linking-privacy-policy/)

Subscribe

We take your privacy seriously, and we will never sell any contact information, including e-mail addresses. For more information about how we store and use your information, see our [privacy policy](/about-us/library-policies/linking-privacy-policy/ "Linking & Privacy Policy").

About Our Mailing Lists Database trainings

Receive reminders about our [Lexis training](/about-us/public-services/lexis-training/ "Lexis Training") sessions.

About 1 e-mail per month.

Newsletter

Stay up-to-date on our latest [Library Spotlight](/spotlight/ "Spotlight") blog posts and news about the library! The Library Spotlight blog highlights new library features, answers to common questions about Texas law, important legal news and developments, and more.

About 1 – 2 e-mails per month.

[home](/ "Home") » [about us](/about-us/ "About Us") » [public services](/about-us/public-services/ "Public Services") » reference librarians

Reference Librarians

Reference librarians are available to help library users locate information, identify relevant resources, and develop search strategies. Our librarians are careful to avoid the unauthorized practice of law (see and ) and as such cannot give legal opinions, advice, or interpretation. We do not have attorneys on staff to advise you on how the law applies to a particular legal situation.

The library is available to:

  * Assist you in locating materials available to us relevant to your research
  * Recommend law books and websites on a particular topic
  * Provide assistance in how to use the library's resources
  * Help locate broad definitions of legal words or phrases
  * Locate areas in state and federal statutes, regulations, and rules to help you begin your research
  * Refer you to other agencies or organizations for assistance



For some of the more common legal questions, we have compiled a list of [frequently asked legal questions](/faqs/ "FAQs"). For patrons who are interested in doing their own legal research, we also make available an as well as (_e.g._ , debt collection; landlord/tenant law; divorce and child support).

For more complex questions we will conduct a reference interview to determine what type of information you require. We will then search resources available to us that we can recommend to you. Some questions are best researched by the patron at a law library. Library staff may ask you to visit the library or point you to a [law library in your area](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-texas/ "County Law Libraries") as legal research is frequently complex even for what may seem like a simple yes or no question.

**Library staff cannot give legal advice. We cannot** :

  * Interpret the meaning of sources or determine their relevance to your specific situation
  * Advise you of your legal rights or recommend a course of action
  * Determine whether an action or practice is legal
  * Select specific statutes, regulations, rules, or forms for your fact situation
  * Recommend a specific attorney
  * Provide case law subject searching
  * Complete forms or handle your personal data



We provide telephone reference to patrons who call our main number . At the discretion of the librarian taking the phone call, over the phone we can:

  * Read brief portions of statutes, regulations, rules, and definitions
  * Search our catalog to see if we have a particular item in our collection
  * Guide you to pre-compiled legal information



Our staff strives to serve all library patrons. Due to the volume of reference requests, the time spent with individuals needs to be limited. When providing telephone or chat reference, we will spend approximately 5-10 minutes per interaction. For any patrons requiring further assistance, the librarian will get contact information and provide follow up information afterwards to the patron. Reference librarians are restricted in the length of time spent assisting individuals. We are unable to provide in-depth research for patrons. Please note that the library is unable to accommodate requests for assistance by a particular staff member.

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:50 PM

**How are we doing? !**

    * [ Legal FAQs](/faqs/)
    * [ Law Libraries of Texas](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-texas/)
    * [ Law Libraries of Other States](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-other-states/)



[home](/ "Home") » [about us](/about-us/ "About Us") » [public services](/about-us/public-services/ "Public Services") » lexis training

Lexis Training

Lexis training sessions are conducted by a Lexis representative. Each session qualifies for 1 hour of continuing legal education (CLE) credit. The sessions are free and open to the public, but they are limited to 20 participants. To receive announcements, please [sign up for our mailing list](/about-us/public-services/mailing-list/ "Mailing List"). The class schedule for this month and a description of the training is available below.

If you are unable to attend our training sessions, Lexis also provides online tutorials and support for . This support is free but is not eligible for CLE credit.

**Date** | **Lexis Training** | **Location**  
---|---|---  
None at this time.  
  
About the Trainings

  * **Understanding Legislation** focuses on conducting statutory and legislative history research using Lexis.
  * **Advanced Legal Research** is aimed at those who are already familiar with Lexis Advance and would like to learn more about its advanced features and use.
  * **COVID-19 Rapid Response: Staying on Top of Legal Changes in a Pandemic** focuses on how to Identify new legal obligations and track legal changes and developments during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, using various on-lines sources and content types.
  * **Leveraging Technology to Prepare Briefs** focuses on the importance of accuracy and efficiency in the review and preparation of briefs and motions.
  * **Eliminating Bias in the Legal Profession** covers different types of bias and provides real-world examples and statistics that can help attorneys identify and combat bias.
  * **Docket Research and Litigation Strategies** focuses on the importance of docket research and explores the best ways to utilize the resources available in Lexis.



page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:50 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [about us](/about-us/ "About Us") » [public services](/about-us/public-services/ "Public Services") » wi-fi in the library

Wi-Fi in the Library

Free wireless Internet access is available at the library for individuals with wireless-enabled laptop computers or devices. This service allows you to quickly and easily connect to and access the library's online catalog and the internet.

You will need:

  * A laptop computer or electronic device with an 802.11b or 802.11g compatible wireless Ethernet network card
  * Software to support the wireless network card
  * A web browser (, , , , , etc.)



To get connected, use the following configuration settings. If you need assistance accessing the wireless service, please see our [troubleshooting guide](/about-us/public-services/wi-fi-in-the-library/troubleshooting-guide/ "Troubleshooting Guide"). Staff assistance is not available for configuring your wireless connection.

SSID (network name): Judicial_GuestPassword:_password is posted at the reference desk_

Printing and access to library databases are not available with the wireless connection. You must use a library workstation to access our electronic databases.

Limitations and Disclosures

The network administrator reserves the right to remove or block any computer or device that is believed to pose a security risk from the network.

There are always security risks when using wireless networks. Information sent to and from your device could be captured by other individuals with appropriate software.

Please note that the library staff is not permitted to handle your laptop, device, network card, or configuration settings. The library cannot accept the liability of handling your equipment. If you need assistance, contact the manufacturer of your hardware or software.

Library staff members are not able to provide technical assistance to you, and there is no guarantee that you will be able to make a wireless connection. However, staff can provide you with a [troubleshooting guide](/about-us/public-services/wi-fi-in-the-library/troubleshooting-guide/ "Troubleshooting Guide") to help you with your configuration.

The library is not responsible for any changes you make to your device's settings.

Wireless access is available during business hours, from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. Printing is not available from the wireless network.

The wireless system is accessible from most of the public areas within the library. Due to the nature of the wireless signal, there may be some weak signal areas in the library.

[home](/ "Home") » library resources

Library Resources

In addition to our extensive print collection, our library offers online resources like legal databases, continuing legal education materials (CLEs), historical Texas statutes, and a collection of restrictions after a felony conviction.

Use the links below to explore the library's resources.

  * [Collections](/library-resources/collections/)
    * [Attorney General Opinions (1891–1938)](/library-resources/collections/attorney-general-opinions-1891-1938/)
    * [The Constitution of the State of Texas: An Annotated and Comparative Analysis](/library-resources/collections/bradens-annotated-texas-constitution/)
    * [Continuing Legal Education Materials](/library-resources/collections/continuing-legal-education-materials/)
    * [Digital Collection](/library-resources/collections/digital-collection/)
    * [Electronic Databases](/library-resources/collections/electronic-databases/)
    * [Historical Texas Statutes](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/)
    * [Law Reviews](/library-resources/collections/law-reviews/)
    * [Law Practice Management](/library-resources/collections/law-practice-management/)
    * [Legislative Recaps of the 88th Legislature (2023)](/library-resources/collections/legislative-recaps/)
    * [Parole & Mandatory Supervision Law](/library-resources/collections/parole-mandatory-supervision-law/)
    * [Print Materials](/library-resources/collections/print-materials/)
    * [Recommended Titles and Treatises](/library-resources/collections/recommended-titles-and-treatises/)
    * [Restrictions After a Felony Conviction](/library-resources/collections/restrictions-after-a-felony-conviction/)
    * [State of the Judiciary Messages](/library-resources/collections/state-of-the-judiciary-messages/)
  * [Conference Room](/library-resources/conference-room/)
  * [Photocopiers](/library-resources/photocopiers/)
  * [Public Computers](/library-resources/public-computers/)
  * [Scanners](/library-resources/scanner/)

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » collections

Collections

The library has an extensive collection of legal resources available to the public. The library's collection consists of Texas and Federal primary law materials including the , the , the , , the , and the . It also includes legal treatises, practice guides, form books, law journals, magazines, newspapers, the National Reporter System, and the American Law Reports.

The library is also proud to provide access to some of our own content. The reference librarians have compiled an annotated and searchable list of [recommended titles and treatises](# "Recommended Titles and Treatises"), arranged by subject matter. Similarly, we have also highlighted a large selection of our [continuing legal education materials](/library-resources/collections/law-reviews/ "Continuing Legal Education Materials") for attorneys and other members of the judiciary. We also strive to keep our compilation of [restrictions after a felony conviction in Texas](# "Restrictions on Convicted Felons") current.

Use the links below to explore our collections.

  * [Attorney General Opinions (1891–1938)](/library-resources/collections/attorney-general-opinions-1891-1938/)
  * [The Constitution of the State of Texas: An Annotated and Comparative Analysis](/library-resources/collections/bradens-annotated-texas-constitution/)
  * [Continuing Legal Education Materials](/library-resources/collections/continuing-legal-education-materials/)
  * [Digital Collection](/library-resources/collections/digital-collection/)
  * [Electronic Databases](/library-resources/collections/electronic-databases/)
  * [Historical Texas Statutes](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/)
  * [Law Reviews](/library-resources/collections/law-reviews/)
  * [Law Practice Management](/library-resources/collections/law-practice-management/)
  * [Legislative Recaps of the 88th Legislature (2023)](/library-resources/collections/legislative-recaps/)
  * [Parole & Mandatory Supervision Law](/library-resources/collections/parole-mandatory-supervision-law/)
  * [Print Materials](/library-resources/collections/print-materials/)
  * [Recommended Titles and Treatises](/library-resources/collections/recommended-titles-and-treatises/)
  * [Restrictions After a Felony Conviction](/library-resources/collections/restrictions-after-a-felony-conviction/)
  * [State of the Judiciary Messages](/library-resources/collections/state-of-the-judiciary-messages/)

Attorney General Opinions (1891–1938)

Prior to 1939, the publication of Texas Attorney General opinions was not systematic or comprehensive. These early opinions were not numbered sequentially like they are . The opinions found on this page are extracted from biennial reports from the attorney general. We provide the cover page and, whenever available, the table of contents of each biennial report along with the opinions themselves and any indexes from the report that may help you locate a particular opinion.

**Note** : The 1901–1902, 1903–1904, and 1904–1906 biennial reports do not contain any opinions, so they are not included here. We also do not have access to a report for 1910–1912. Reports prior to 1912–1914 did not have tables of contents.

[1891–1892](#1891-1892) | [1893–1894](#1893-1894) | [1895–1896](#1895-1896) | [1897–1898](#1897-1898) | [1899–1900](#1899-1900) | [1906–1908](#1906-1908) | [1908–1910](#1908-1910) | [1912–1914](#1912-1914) | [1914–1916](#1914-1916) | [1916–1918](#1916-1918) | [1918–1920](#1918-1920) | [1920–1922](#1920-1922) | [1922–1924](#1922-1924) | [1924–1926](#1924-1926) | [1926–1928](#1926-1928) | [1928–1930](#1928-1930) | [1930–1932](#1930-1932) | [1932–1934](#1932-1934) | [1934–1936](#1934-1936) | [1936–1938](#1936-1938) | ![](/assets/images/external-link.png)

1891–1892Charles A. Culberson [![](/assets/images/attorney-general-opinions/ag-report-cover-1891-1892.png)](/assets/images/attorney-general-opinions/ag-report-cover-1891-1892.png "click to view full-size image") Click to enlarge image.

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » [collections](/library-resources/collections/ "Collections") » braden's annotated texas constitution

The Constitution of the State of Texas: An Annotated and Comparative Analysis

In 1972, Texas voters approved a revision of the state's constitution. Prior to this revision, Professor George D. Braden and others began research in order to “provide information to aid the constitutional revision process.”

In this publication, the authors provide information regarding the origins, historical development, and contemporary meaning of each section of the . The authors also add interpretive comments. Researchers of the Texas constitution, then and now, find this publication an invaluable resource.

In the foreword, James F. Ray, director of the Texas Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, states that the principal reason for the publication was to make the information available to the public. Now the library is privileged to bring this publication to you electronically.

The library expresses its gratitude to the estate of George Braden and to the authors for allowing us to digitize and provide access to _The Constitution of the State of Texas: An Annotated and Comparative Analysis_.

This digitized version of Braden's publication was made possible thanks to a grant from the of the and with the permission of the numerous authors. Please [contact us](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) if you run into technical issues.

    * [Article XVII](/assets/pdf/braden/42-article-xvii.pdf)
    * Conclusion 
      * [Table of Cases, Table of Texas Attorney General Opinions and Letters Advisory](/assets/pdf/braden/43-table-of-cases-table-of-texas-oag-opinions.pdf)
      * [Secondary Sources](/assets/pdf/braden/44-secondary-sources.pdf)
      * [Index](/assets/pdf/braden/45-index.pdf)



Adobe Reader or other PDF software is required to view PDFs. .

Download

The entire book can be downloaded for your convenience. The PDF has been bookmarked for ease of use.

[Download PDF (60.4 MB)](/assets/pdf/braden/the-constitution-of-the-state-of-texas-an-annotated-and-comparative-analysis.pdf) [Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/bradens-annotated-texas-constitution/bookreader/)

Search

Search the contents of the book below.

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » [collections](/library-resources/collections/ "Collections") » continuing legal education materials

Continuing Legal Education Materials

The library receives continuing legal education (CLE) materials from the State Bar of Texas. These courses allow attorneys to earn CLE credit, which is required by the Bar.

CLE materials from 2017 onward are available as e-books you can borrow with your [library account](/about-us/get-a-library-account/).

If you are interested in CLE materials only available in print but cannot visit the library in Austin, [contact us](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) about our fee-based [document delivery](/about-us/public-services/document-delivery/) service.

Find a CLE Course 

Search 

use quotation marks to search for "complete phrases" use an asterisk * as a wildcard (leas* searches for lease, leases, leasing, etc.)

Search

Electronic Databases

Availability of Databases

Library databases are always available on the library's public computers.

In addition, some databases and e-books can be accessed from home using your library card number and password. If you are a Texas resident but don't have a library account with us, you may **[register for a library account online](http://www.sll.texas.gov/about-us/get-a-library-card "Get a Library Card")**.

The icons below indicate any additional access or restrictions.

![Computer icon used to indicate a resource available from a library computer](https://lgimages.s3.amazonaws.com/data/imagemanager/66807/computer_64x64.png) **Only from a library computer**

![Library card icon used to indicate a resource available with a library card](https://lgimages.s3.amazonaws.com/data/imagemanager/66807/id-card-icon_16x16.png) **From any computer with a valid library account**

![World icon used to indicate a resource available to everyone](https://lgimages.s3.amazonaws.com/data/imagemanager/66807/web_32x32.png) **Available to everyone from any computer**

**Disclaimer:** **The State Law Library cannot tell you what a law means for your situation.**

**Ask a Librarian**

  * [Ask a Librarian](https://www.sll.texas.gov/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian")
  * [Law Libraries of Texas](https://www.sll.texas.gov/self-help/where-to-go-for-help/law-libraries-of-texas/ "Law Libraries of Texas")



**Contact an Attorney**

  * [Legal Help & Information](https://www.sll.texas.gov/legal-help/ "Legal Help & Information")

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » [collections](/library-resources/collections/ "Collections") » historical texas statutes

Historical Texas Statutes

The library's digitization efforts have brought online over 100 years of historical Texas statutes. We provide free public access to [digitized copies of Texas statutes](#navigation) from 1879 through 1984.

About Printed Statutes

In 1854, the state legislature authorized a commission to codify existing laws. The were completed in 1856. The civil statutes followed in [1879](#1879). Subsequent revisions and recodifications followed in [1895](#1895) and [1911](#1911). In [1925](#1925), there was a reorganization of the statutes, which still serves as the basis for our current statutes.

Between the years of 1911 and 1925, there was not an “official” publication of Texas statutes even though the legislature continued to meet every other year to write and amend laws.

To fill in the gaps in the official statutes, publisher John Sayles and his son Henry Sayles compiled and published unofficial volumes of Texas statutes in 1914. Called “Vernon’s Sayles’” after the publisher, these volumes contain the text of statutes, valuable annotations, and indexes from 1911 through 1921.

After 1925, the evolution of the Texas statutes is more complicated. The statutes are not reprinted in their entirety after each legislative session. Instead, the few complete reprintings of the statutes are updated with supplemental volumes after regular legislative sessions, which occur every 2 years.

The library thanks Thomson Reuters, current copyright holders of the printed Texas statutes, for allowing us to provide access to the statutes from 1928 onward.

Availability Years | Source  
---|---  
Before 1879 |  — Legislative Reference Library  
1879 – 1984 | [Statutes by Year](#navigation) — State Law Library  
1985 – 2004 | Not online* — see note below  
2004 – present |  — Texas Legislature Online  
  
*There is no free, public online source for codified Texas statutes in effect between the last volume on this page and 2004. For these intervening years, see the session laws available on the from the Legislative Reference Library.

Our library has an extensive print collection of historical Texas statutes, and we make these available to the public during [business hours](http://www.sll.texas.gov/about-us/about-the-library/#hours "About the Library"). If you cannot visit the library in person, [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian") for assistance.

Tips

  * To see how a statute read on a particular date, you may need to consult both a base volume from one of the complete reprintings alongside one or more supplemental volumes.
  * We recommend the PDFs for advanced research. Each file is bookmarked with a table of contents for navigation.
  * To search or print from a volume, use the PDF version in your web browser or with PDF software — _e.g._ , .



[Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) for assistance navigating historical Texas statutes.

Learn More

  * [Texas Statutes](/law-legislation/texas/statutes/ "Statutes")Information about legislative history and intent, bills, and session laws.
  * Contains a discussion of the continuing statutory revision project.
  * A comprehensive guide to print sources of Texas statutes, both official and unofficial.



Statutes by Year [1879](#1879) | [1895](#1895) | [1911](#1911) | [1914](#1914) | [1916](#1916) | [1918 supp.](#1918) | [1920](#1920) | [1922 supp.](#1922) | [1925](#1925) | [1928](#1928) | [1931 supp.](#1931) | [1934 supp.](#1934) | [1936](#1936) | [1938 supp.](#1938) | [1939 supp.](#1939) | [1942 supp.](#1942) | [1945 supp.](#1945) | [1948](#1948) | [1950 supp.](#1950) | [1952 supp.](#1952) | [1954 supp.](#1954) | [1956 supp.](#1956) | [1958 supp.](#1958) | [1960 supp.](#1960) | [1962 supp.](#1962) | [1964 supp.](#1964) | [1966 supp.](#1966) | [1968 supp.](#1968) | [1970 supp.](#1970) | [1972 supp.](#1972) | [1974](#1974) | [1975 supp.](#1975) | [1977 supp.](#1977) | [1979 supp.](#1979) | [1981 supp.](#1981) | [1984](#1984)

1879 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1879-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1879-large.png "view title page")

1879 Revised Statutes of Texas

Published by State Printing Office. Austin. 1887.Digitization funded in part by the .

Statutes Enacted at the | Year  
---|---  
16th Legislature — Regular Session | 1879  
  
[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1879/ "Read in your browser")

The 1879 statutes consist of several individual volumes available for download in PDF format below.

[U.S. Constitution (345 KB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1879/1879-1-constitution-of-the-united-states.pdf "Download PDF") [Texas Constitution (2 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1879/1879-2-constitution-of-the-state-of-texas.pdf "Download PDF") [Revised Civil Statutes (25 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1879/1879-3-revised-civil-statutes-of-the-state-of-texas.pdf "Download PDF") [Penal Code (4 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1879/1879-4-penal-code-of-the-state-of-texas.pdf "Download PDF") [Code of Criminal Procedure (5 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1879/1879-5-code-of-criminal-procedure-of-the-state-of-texas.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1895 Revised Statutes of Texas

Published by Eugene Von Boeckmann. Austin. 1895.Digitization funded in part by the .

Statutes Enacted at the | Year  
---|---

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1914 — unofficial compilation 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1914-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1914-large.png "view title page")

1914 Vernon's Sayles' Annotated Civil Statutes of the State of Texas

Published by Vernon Law Book Company. Kansas City, MO. 1914.

Statutes Enacted through the | Year  
---|---  
32nd Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1911  
33rd Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1913  
  
_Note_ : This unofficial compilation follows the classification of the statutes as adopted in 1911. According to the publisher, laws from 1911 – 1913 are included and inserted under the “most appropriate place in the title they relate.”

**Volume 1** contains the United States Constitution, Constitution of the State of Texas, and Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 1 through 1811—118).

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1914-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (120 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1914-1/1914-1-vernons-sayles-annotated-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 2** contains the Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 1812 through 3639).

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1914-2/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (151 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1914-2/1914-2-vernons-sayles-annotated-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 3** contains the Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 3640 through 5474).

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1914-3/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (155 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1914-3/1914-3-vernons-sayles-annotated-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 4** contains the Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 5475 to End).

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1914-4/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (147 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1914-4/1914-4-vernons-sayles-annotated-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 5** contains the Table of Sessions Laws and General Index.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1914-5/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (34 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1914-5/1914-5-vernons-sayles-annotated-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1916 — unofficial compilation 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1916-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1916-large.png "view title page")

1916 Vernon's Criminal Statutes of Texas

Published by Vernon Law Book Company. Kansas City, MO. 1916.

Statutes Enacted through the | Year  
---|---  
32nd Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1911  
33rd Legislature — Regular Session and 1st through 3rd Called Sessions | 1913 – 1914  
34th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1915  
  
_Note_ : This unofficial compilation provides an interim updated source for criminal laws. According to the preface, in addition to the updated coverage, this is a more correct compilation of the Penal Code and Code of Criminal Procedure than the revision in [1911](#1911). The preface details failings of the [1911](#1911) revision and how the publishers addressed those issues in these volumes.

**Volume 1** contains the Penal Code.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1916-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (115 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1916-1/1916-1-criminal-statutes-of-texas.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 2** contains the Code of Criminal Procedure.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1916-2/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (118 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1916-2/1916-2-criminal-statutes-of-texas.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1918 — supplement to unofficial compilation 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1918-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1918-large.png "view title page")

1918 Supplement to Vernon's Texas Civil and Criminal Statutes

Published by Vernon Law Book Company. Kansas City, MO. 1918.

Statutes Enacted at the | Year  
---|---  
33rd Legislature — 2nd and 3rd Called Sessions | 1914  
34th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1915  
35th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st through 3rd Called Sessions | 1917  
_“except such laws as were carried into Vernon's Criminal Statutes of[1916](#1916)” — preface_  
  
_Note_ : In these unofficial supplements, the preface notes that new laws have been included using the classification adopted in [1911](#1911). “Entirely new provisions are given lettered or hyphenated numbers, and placed in the titles and chapters to which their subject-matter relates.”

**Volume 1** contains the Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 1 through 46071⁄2d).

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1918-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (115 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1918-1/1918-1-supplement-vernons-texas-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 2** contains the Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 4608 to End), Penal Code, and Code of Criminal Procedure, along with their respective Indexes. Volume 2 consists of several individual PDFs available for download below.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1918-2/ "Read in your browser")

Volume 2 is available in PDF format below.

[Civil Statutes—Articles 4608 to End (78 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1918-2/1918-2-1-revised-civil-statutes.pdf "Download PDF") [Penal Code (10 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1918-2/1918-2-2-penal-code.pdf "Download PDF") [Code of Criminal Procedure (13 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1918-2/1918-2-3-code-of-criminal-procedure.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1920 — unofficial compilation 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1920-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1920-large.png "view title page")

1920 Complete Texas Statutes

Published by Vernon Law Book Company. Kansas City, MO. 1920.

Statutes Enacted through the | Year  
---|---  
32nd Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1911  
33rd Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1913 – 1914  
34th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1915  
35th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st through 4th Called Sessions | 1917 – 1918  
36th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st and 2nd Called Sessions | 1919  
_“and statutes enacted prior to 1911 and omitted from the Revised Criminal Statutes 1911” — preface_  
  
_Note_ : This single-volume unofficial compilation provides the “entire existing general statute law of the state” through the 2nd Called Session of the 36th Legislature in 1919. The preface notes that this edition includes the publisher's corrections to “errors and omissions” from the [1911](#1911) revision of the Penal Code and Code of Criminal Procedure, as first noted in the [1916](#1916) unofficial compilation.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1920/ "Read in your browser")

Also available in PDF format below.

[Constitutions and Civil Statutes (257 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1920/1920-1-revised-civil-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")[Penal Code (46 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1920/1920-2-penal-code.pdf "Download PDF") [Code of Criminal Procedure (27 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1920/1920-3-code-of-criminal-procedure.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1922 — supplement to unofficial compilation 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1922-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1922-large.png "view title page")

1922 Supplement to Vernon's Texas Civil and Criminal Statutes

Published by Vernon Law Book Company. Kansas City, MO. 1922.

Statutes Enacted at the | Year  
---|---  
35th Legislature — 4th Called Session | 1918  
36th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st through 4th Called Sessions | 1919 – 1920  
37th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st and 2nd Called Sessions | 1921  
  
_Note_ : In these unofficial supplements, the preface notes that new laws have been included using the classification adopted in [1911](#1911). “Entirely new provisions are given lettered or hyphenated numbers, and placed in the titles and chapters to which their subject-matter relates.”

**Volume 1** contains the United States Constitution, Constitution of the State of Texas, and Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 1 through 4704).

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1922-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (140 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1922-1/1922-1-supplement-vernons-texas-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 2** contains the Annotated Civil Statutes (Articles 4711 to End), the Penal Code, and the Code of Criminal Procedure.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1922-2/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (142 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1922-2/1922-2-supplement-vernons-texas-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 3** contains the Table of Session Laws and General Index.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1922-3 "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (68 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1922-3/1922-3-supplement-vernons-texas-statutes.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

Published by West Publishing Company. St. Paul, Minn. 1974.Digitized with permission from Thomson Reuters. Digitization funded by the .

Statutes Enacted through the | Year  
---|---

_includes the Texas Constitution as amended through November 6, 1973_

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1974-5/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (106 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1974-5/1974-5-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

1977 Supplement to West's [1974 Texas Statutes and Codes](#1974)

Published by West Publishing Company. St. Paul, Minn. 1978.Digitized with permission from Thomson Reuters. Digitization funded by the .

Statutes Enacted at the | Year  
---|---  
64th Legislature — Regular Session | 1975  
65th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1977  
  
**Volume 1** contains the Constitution of the State of Texas; the Alcoholic Beverage Code; the Business and Commerce Code; the Education Code; the Family Code; the Natural Resources Code; the Parks and Wildlife Code; the Penal Code; the Penal Auxiliary Laws; the Code of Criminal Procedure; the Water Code; the Business Corporation Act; Title 32, Corporations, of the Civil Statutes; the Election Code; the Insurance Code; the Probate Code; and Title 122, Taxation, and Title 122A, Taxation—General, of the Civil Statutes.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1977-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (115 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1977-1/1977-1-supplement-to-1974-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 2** contains the Revised Civil Statutes and the Topical Index to the Revised Civil Statutes.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1977-2/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (75 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1977-2/1977-2-supplement-to-1974-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1979 supplement 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1979-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1979-large.png "view title page")

1979 Supplement to West's [1974 Texas Statutes and Codes](#1974)

Published by West Publishing Company. St. Paul, Minn. 1980.Digitized with permission from Thomson Reuters. Digitization funded by the .

Statutes Enacted at the | Year  
---|---  
64th Legislature — Regular Session | 1975  
65th Legislature — Regular Session and the 1st and 2nd Called Sessions | 1977 – 1978  
66th Legislature — Regular Session | 1979  
  
**Volume 1** contains the Constitution of the State of Texas; the Alcoholic Beverage Code; the Business and Commerce Code; the Education Code; the Family Code; the Human Resources Code; the Natural Resources Code; the Parks and Wildlife Code; the Penal Code; the Code of Criminal Procedure; the Tax Code (Property Tax Code); Title 122, Taxation, and Title 122A, Taxation—General, of the Civil Statutes; and the Water Code.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1979-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (119 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1979-1/1979-1-supplement-to-1974-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 2** contains the Business Corporation Act; Title 32, Corporations, of the Civil Statutes; the Election Code; the Insurance Code; the Probate Code; the Revised Civil Statutes; and the Topical Index to the Revised Civil Statutes.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1979-2/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (141 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1979-2/1979-2-supplement-to-1974-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

_Note_ : To print or perform advanced full-text searching, we recommend you use the PDF versions in your browser or with software such as the free .

1981 supplement 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1981-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1981-large.png "view title page")

1981 Supplement to West's [1974 Texas Statutes and Codes](#1974)

Published by West Publishing Company. St. Paul, Minn. 1982.Digitized with permission from Thomson Reuters. Digitization funded by the .

Statutes Enacted at the | Year  
---|---  
64th Legislature — Regular Session | 1975  
65th Legislature — Regular Session and the 1st and 2nd Called Sessions | 1977 – 1978  
66th Legislature — Regular Session | 1979  
67th Legislature — Regular Session and 1st Called Session | 1981  
  
**Volume 1** contains the Constitution of the State of Texas; the Agriculture Code; the Alcoholic Beverage Code; the Business and Commerce Code; the Education Code; the Family Code; the Human Resources Code; the Natural Resources Code; the Parks and Wildlife Code; the Penal Code; the Code of Criminal Procedure; the Tax Code; Title 122, Taxation, and Title 122A, Taxation—General, of the Civil Statutes; and the Water Code.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1981-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (165 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1981-1/1981-1-supplement-to-1974-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Volume 2** contains the Business Corporation Act; Title 32, Corporations, of the Civil Statutes; the Election Code; the Insurance Code; the Probate Code; the Revised Civil Statutes; and the Topical Index to the Revised Civil Statutes.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1981-2/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (194 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1981-2/1981-2-supplement-to-1974-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

1984 

[![title page](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1984-small.png)](/assets/images/historical-statutes/title-pages/1984-large.png "view title page")

1984 West's Texas Statutes and Codes with Supplements

Published by West Publishing Company. St. Paul, Minn. 1984.Digitized with permission from Thomson Reuters. Digitization funded by the .

Statutes Enacted through the | Year  
---|---  
68th Legislature — Regular Session and the 1st and 2nd Called Sessions | 1983 – 1984  
  
**Civil Statutes (Articles 1 – 1273)** as amended through the 1983 Regular and 1st Called Sessions of the 68th Legislature, the text of the Texas Constitution as amended through the November 8, 1983, general election, and the proposed amendments to the Constitution to be voted upon at the November 6, 1984, general election.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-1/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (100 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-1/1984-1-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Civil Statutes (Articles 1274 – 4413)** as amended through the 1983 Regular and 1st Called Sessions of the 68th Legislature.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-2/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (76 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-2/1984-2-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Civil Statutes (Articles 4414 – 5433)** as amended through the 1983 Regular and 1st Called Sessions of the 68th Legislature.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-3/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (75 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-3/1984-3-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Civil Statutes (Articles 5434 – 6812)** as amended through the 1983 Regular and 1st Called Sessions of the 68th Legislature.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-4/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (77 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-4/1984-4-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Civil Statutes (Articles 6813 – End)** as amended through the 1983 Regular and 1st Called Sessions of the 68th Legislature. The Civil Statutes are followed by a descriptive word Index.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-5/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (66 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-5/1984-5-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

**Civil Statutes, Supplement,** as amended through the 1984 2nd Called Session of the 68th Legislature. The Titles amended during this session include Title 8; Title 15; Title 20; Title 20A; Title 22; Title 28; Title 41; Title 44; Title 70; Title 71; Title 87; Title 110B; Title 115; Title 116; Title 130; and Title 132.

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-6/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (6 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-6/1984-supplement-to-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

[Read in your browser](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-HR/ "Read in your browser") [Download PDF (10 MB)](/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-HR/1984-human-resources-code-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf "Download PDF")

https://www.sll.texas.gov/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-PE-2/
https://www.sll.texas.gov/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-PE-2/1984-supplement-to-penal-code-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf
https://www.sll.texas.gov/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-PR/
https://www.sll.texas.gov/assets/pdf/historical-statutes/1984-PR/1984-property-code-wests-texas-statutes-and-codes.pdf
https://www.sll.texas.gov/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/bookreader/1984-PW/

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » [collections](/library-resources/collections/ "Collections") » law reviews

Law Reviews

The library subscribes to over 1,700 law reviews, law journals, and other legal periodicals.

In Print

Periodicals are arranged alphabetically by title in the library mezzanine. To see if we carry a certain title, check our .

Online

With a [library account](/about-us/get-a-library-account/ "Get a Library Account"), you have access to the.

Some additional online options that do not require a library account:

  * The section of the includes open-access scholarly articles published by more than 395 institutions.
  * The website provides access to over 200 open-access law reviews.
  * has academic papers, article pre-prints, and certain legal documents such as published opinions. See the page.



page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:55 PM

Law Practice Management

Below we highlight titles that can help attorneys manage their law practice.

If you have questions, you can [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/). 

Find Books and E-Books 

Search 

use quotation marks to search for "complete phrases" use an asterisk * as a wildcard (leas* searches for lease, leases, leasing, etc.) 

  * [Attorney Liability](?subject-id=303&subject-name=attorney-liability "See titles related to Attorney Liability")
  * [Attorney Well-Being](?subject-id=304&subject-name=attorney-well-being "See titles related to Attorney Well-Being")
  * [Building Your Own Practice](?subject-id=305&subject-name=building-your-own-practice "See titles related to Building Your Own Practice")
  * [Career Information](?subject-id=306&subject-name=career-information "See titles related to Career Information")
  * [Citations](?subject-id=307&subject-name=citations "See titles related to Citations")
  * [Collaborative Law](?subject-id=308&subject-name=collaborative-law "See titles related to Collaborative Law")
  * [Compensation and Billing](?subject-id=309&subject-name=compensation-and-billing "See titles related to Compensation and Billing")
  * [General Law Practice Management](?subject-id=310&subject-name=general-law-practice-management "See titles related to General Law Practice Management")
  * [General Legal Research and Writing](?subject-id=311&subject-name=general-legal-research-and-writing "See titles related to General Legal Research and Writing")
  * [Information Security](?subject-id=312&subject-name=information-security "See titles related to Information Security")
  * [Legal Composition and Draftmanship](?subject-id=313&subject-name=legal-composition-and-draftmanship "See titles related to Legal Composition and Draftmanship")
  * [Legal History](?subject-id=314&subject-name=legal-history "See titles related to Legal History")
  * [Legal Research](?subject-id=315&subject-name=legal-research "See titles related to Legal Research")
  * [Legal Research on the Internet](?subject-id=316&subject-name=legal-research-on-the-internet "See titles related to Legal Research on the Internet")
  * [Managing Your Practice](?subject-id=317&subject-name=managing-your-practice "See titles related to Managing Your Practice")
  * [Records Management](?subject-id=318&subject-name=records-management "See titles related to Records Management")
  * [Solo Practitioners/Small Firms](?subject-id=319&subject-name=solo-practitionerssmall-firms "See titles related to Solo Practitioners/Small Firms")
  * [Technology](?subject-id=320&subject-name=technology "See titles related to Technology")

Legislative Recaps of the 88th Legislature (2023)

The meets regularly every 2 years (on odd-numbered years). At the end of a regular legislative session, hundreds of passed bills are sent to the governor for approval. Due to the very large number of bills and the wide variety of topics they cover, it can be difficult to get an understanding of all the new laws that were passed.

To help the public become aware of new laws, many organizations provide summaries of new legislation. Below we highlight some of the legislative summaries published by news organizations, state agencies, professional organizations, and independent writers.

Some legislative summaries may be written before the governor's veto period ends. We recommended consulting to check that a bill was not vetoed.

Regular Session

  * by the Texas Tribune
  * by the Legislative Reference Library of Texas
  * by the Legislative Reference Library of Texas
  * by the Texas Legislative Study Group
  * by KSAT

1st Called Session
  * by the Texas Legislative Study Group

2nd Called Session
  * by the Texas Legislative Study Group

3rd Called Session
  * by the Texas Legislative Study Group
  * by Houston Public Media

4th Called Session
  * by the Texas Legislative Study Group
  * by the Austin-American Statesman
  * by KUT News

New Laws Effective September 1st, 2023
  * [subscribers only] by the Dallas Morning News
  * by KVUE
  * by Axios Dallas
  * [subscribers only] by the Houston Chronicle
  * by KSAT

New Laws Effective January 1, 2024
  * by the Texas Legislative Reference Library

Agriculture
  * [podcast] by Texas A&M AgriLife Extension: Ag Law in the Field

Business & Consumer Law
  * by the National Law Review
  * by the National Law Review

Criminal Law
  * by Texas Center for Justice & Equity
  * by Varghese Summersett
  * by Texas Department of Criminal Justice

Disability Policy
  * [YouTube video] by the Texas Council for Developmental Disabilities

Education
  * by the Association of Texas Professional Educators
  * by Texas Association of School Administrators
  * by the Texas Tribune
  * by KUT
  * by KHOU

Elections
  * by the Texas Secretary of State

Employment
  * by the Employment Law Handbook
  * Texas Governor Signs Preemption Bill, CROWN Act and Other Bills by the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

Environmental Policy
  * by Texas Commission on Environmental Quality
  * by the National Law Review

Family Law
  * by McClure Law Group

Firearms
  * by the Texas Tribune
  * by National Rifle Association Institute for Legislative Action

Healthcare
  * by Texas Medical Association
  * by Community Impact
  * by Norton Rose Fulbright 
  * by KERA News
  * by the Texas Tribune

Immigration
  * by Texas Public Radio
  * by KUT News
  * by the Texas Tribune

Insurance
  * by Independent Insurance Agents of Texas

LGBTQ+ Law
  * by the National Law Review
  * by the Texas Tribune

Licensing and Regulation
  * by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation

Local Government
  * by the Texas Municipal League
  * by the Texas Association of Counties

Probate, Guardianship, and Trust Law
  * by Karisch Jonas Law
  * by the Dallas Morning News

Property Owners’ Associations (HOAs)
  * by the National Law Review
  * by FirstService Residential
  * by RMWBH

Property Taxes
  * by the Office of the Texas Governor
  * by the Texas Tribune

Public Information
  * by the Attorney General of Texas

Real Estate
  * by the National Law Review
  * by the National Law Review
  * by the Texas Real Estate Commission
  * by the Texas Real Estate Commission
  * by the Texas Real Estate Commission
  * by the Texas Real Estate Commission

Retirement
  * by the Teacher Retirement System of Texas
  * by the Employee Retirement System of Texas

Sports Betting
  * by Blank Rome

Tax Policy
  * by the Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts

Technology
  * by the National Law Review
  * by the Texas Department of Information Resources
  * by the National Law Review

Utilities
  * by the National Law Review



_Disclaimer_ : The sites listed above are hosted by third-party organizations and are intended as informational sources for the public. The library does not endorse any political messages these sources may contain. Please see our [third-party linking policy](/about-us/library-policies/linking-privacy-policy/ "Linking & Privacy Policy") for more information.

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » [collections](/library-resources/collections/ "Collections") » parole & mandatory supervision law

Parole & Mandatory Supervision Law

The library often receives questions about parole and mandatory supervision law and whether an inmate is eligible for parole.

The decides which eligible offenders will be released on parole or discretionary mandatory supervision. Their website provides and information about .

The and the publish , a guide that helps provide accurate information about parole and mandatory supervision. is available for free in both English and Spanish.

Parole and Mandatory Supervision Laws

Texas parole and mandatory supervision laws have a long history of revisions and amendments. Questions about eligibility and other parole issues usually require that you look at the parole law that was in place on a specific date — for example, the date of a conviction or the date of the offense that led to a conviction.

If you are looking for parole law as it existed on a specific date, please see the information below.

Early 2004 – Present

The current version of the parole and supervision statutes is available online via . Sections and , which relate to eligibility for parole and mandatory supervision, refer you to the list of offenses found in of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

You can see any version of these statutes from early 2004 to the present by using the feature on the Texas Legislature's website. On that page, you can access the law as of any specific date after the 10th of January 2004.

Before January 11th, 2004

To locate the parole and mandatory supervision laws for a date prior to January 11th, 2004, we invite you to [submit a request](/about-us/library-policies/ "Ask a Librarian") to the library. Through our fee-based [Document Delivery](/about-us/public-services/document-delivery/ "Document Delivery") service, we can provide copies of the law either in print or electronically. You can also [visit a law library in person](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-texas/ "Law Libraries of Texas") in order to view previous versions of the law.

If you wish to do this historical legal research on your own, we invite you to use our [Historical Texas Statutes](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/ "Historical Texas Statutes") collection online. Our library digitized historical publications of the Texas statutes from 1879 through 1984.

Please [contact us](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) if you have questions about locating parole and mandatory supervision laws.

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:55 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » [collections](/library-resources/collections/ "Collections") » print materials

Print Materials

The library is open to the public and has a circulating collection of over 100,000 volumes.

Some of our most commonly used primary law materials include the , the , the , , the , and the .

In addition to primary law, our collection contains legal treatises, practice guides, form books, law journals, magazines, newspapers, the National Reporter System, and the American Law Reports. We have a special collection of rare books and old British law and statutes. While we are a selective depository library, we do not receive many new federal government documents.

See our selection of [recommended titles and treatises](/library-resources/collections/recommended-titles-and-treatises/ "Recommended Titles and Treatises") for highlights from our print collection. Our collection includes many [continuing legal education materials](/library-resources/collections/continuing-legal-education-materials/ "Continuing Legal Education Materials") from the State Bar of Texas.

Our [Library Use Policy](/about-us/library-policies/library-use-policy/ "Library Use Policy") has details about borrowing materials from the library. If you have any questions about the materials available at the library, you may [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/).

Recommended Titles and Treatises

Our librarians selected noteworthy titles from our collection and we feature them here by subject.

To request an excerpt from a print resource through our fee-based [document delivery service](/about-us/public-services/document-delivery/ "Document Delivery"), please [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian") for assistance.

Find a Book 

Search 

use quotation marks to search for "complete phrases" use an asterisk * as a wildcard (leas* searches for lease, leases, leasing, etc.) 

  * [Administrative Law](?subject-id=6&subject-name=administrative-law "See titles related to Administrative Law")

Restrictions After a Felony Conviction

Time in prison is often not the only consequence of a felony conviction in Texas.

This collection features [statutes](/law-legislation/texas/statutes/ "Statutes"), [regulations](/law-legislation/texas/administrative-rules/ "Administrative Rules"), and [state](/the-courts/texas-court-rules/ "Texas Court Rules") and [federal](/the-courts/federal-court-rules/ "Federal Court Rules") court rules that place restrictions on people with a felony conviction.

[Browse Felony Restrictions](/library-resources/collections/restrictions-after-a-felony-conviction/?view=home "Restrictions After a Felony Conviction") [Browse Employment-Related Restrictions](/library-resources/collections/restrictions-after-a-felony-conviction/?view=home#professions)

Not Comprehensive

This is**not** a list of all the laws that affect a person with a felony conviction. There are hundreds of statutes that refer to previous criminal convictions. This collection lists laws for some common situations.

For a more complete listing, see the . It is a collection of laws with consequences that people with criminal records face in the United States. The information is from a study conducted by the National Institute of Justicethe U.S. Congress.

Talk to a Lawyer

It can be hard to assess the impact of your criminal record. Sometimes the language in a law can leave room for interpretation. The courts may determine how the law applies in different cases.

You should speak to a lawyer about how a felony conviction may apply to your situation. See ourguide for options.

**How are we doing? !**

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » [collections](/library-resources/collections/ "Collections") » state of the judiciary messages

State of the Judiciary Messages

Every two years, the chief justice of the prepares a state of the judiciary message. This message is usually delivered as a speech given to a joint session of the legislature. The audience at the joint session includes representatives, senators, and often also includes members of the judiciary and other dignitaries.

This message is mandated by :

> (a) At a convenient time at the commencement of each regular session of the legislature, the chief justice of the supreme court shall deliver a written or oral state of the judiciary message evaluating the accessibility of the courts to the citizens of the state and the future directions and needs of the courts of the state.
> 
> (b) It is the intent of the legislature that the state of the judiciary message promote better understanding between the legislative and judicial branches of government and promote more efficient administration of justice in Texas.

The mandating a state of the judiciary message passed in 1977 during the 65th Legislature. The law was as part of a nonsubstantive revision of statutes relating to the judiciary. It was then to specify that the message may be written or oral.

The library gives special thanks to the and the for previously digitizing some of these messages.

Search the Transcripts

Use "quotation marks" to search for phrases (_e.g._ , "legal aid").

State of the Judiciary Messages Search Form **Search term(s):**

match any word/phrase  match all words/phrases

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » conference room

Conference Room

The library has a conference room available during regular [library hours](/about-us/about-the-library/#hours "About the Library"). It is primarily reserved for library staff meetings and programs but can also be used by any:

  * government agencies;
  * bar associations;
  * judicial bodies;
  * non-profit organizations; or
  * licensed attorneys.



If your organization would like to reserve our conference room, you can make a pending reservation below. There is no charge to use the conference room.

We reserve the right to review, accept, or reject any or all requests for conference room use. By using the conference room, you agree to abide by our [conference room policy](/about-us/library-policies/conference-room-policy/ "Conference Room Policy").

Reserve the Conference Room

You may make a reservation in person, by phone at , or online. To make a request online:

  1. **Click the time you'd like in the calendar and add the required information**. Once submitted, requests will show as "Reserved" on the calendar. Your personal information is not visible. You have 30 minutes to edit your information or delete your request after you submit.
  2. **Library staff will review your request and send you a confirmation e-mail**. Requests are considered pending until you receive a confirmation e-mail. We will e-mail you if there is an issue with your reservation.



Please [let us know](/about-us/contact-us/ "Contact Us") if you need to cancel or change your reservation.

SLL Conference Room

Self-reservation

[Login](/login)

[Register](/register)

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » photocopiers

Photocopiers

The library has a black & white photocopier available for public use. Photocopies cost $0.15 per page. The copier accepts credit cards, coins, $1 bills, and $5 bills. 

Patrons who require an itemized receipt for use of the photocopier should speak to the librarian at the reference desk prior to making copies.

page last updated: 19 Jul 2023 5:00 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » public computers

Public Computers

The library has 4 computers available for patrons with a [library account](/about-us/get-a-library-account/ "Get a Library Account") in good standing. The computers provide access to:

  * the internet;
  * the library's electronic resources (legal databases, e-books, etc.); and
  * word processing software.



Black and white printing from the public computer terminals is available at $0.25 per page plus sales tax.

Use of the library computers is subject to the [Computer Use Policy](/about-us/library-policies/computer-use-policy/ "Computer Use Policy"). Reserve a Computer

Reservations may be made online using our . Reservations are not required, and computers are otherwise available on a first-come first-serve basis.

See the [Computer Use Policy](/about-us/library-policies/computer-use-policy/) for more information.

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:51 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [library resources](/library-resources/ "Library Resources") » scanner

Scanners

The library has two scanners available for public use. There is no cost to use the scanners.

Both scanners have face-up scanning beds allowing patrons to scan a variety of materials. Once the pages have been scanned, it is possible to edit them by cropping the scan, adjusting contrast and brightness, rotating the scan, changing the resolution, and changing the scan from color to black and white.

The scanners allow patrons to save scans in a variety of formats including searchable .pdf, .jpeg, .png, rich text format, or as an audio file. These files can be saved to a flash drive, e-mailed, or uploaded to cloud services. Flash drives can be purchased at the reference desk.

Patrons are required to follow all copyright laws when using a scanner.

[home](/ "Home") » law & legislation

Law & Legislation

The structure and purpose of the federal government is set out in the constitution. The federal government enacts statutes through the Congress. Federal agencies are given rulemaking authority by Congress. The federal courts interpret the law.

Each of the 50 states has its own system of government.

In Texas, the state legislature enacts statutes. State agencies are given rulemaking authority by the legislature. Local governments like municipalities and counties may then enact ordinances within their jurisdictions. The state courts interpret the law.

Use the pages below to learn more.

  * [Texas Law & Legislation](/law-legislation/texas/)
    * [Texas Constitution](/law-legislation/texas/constitution/)
    * [Texas Statutes](/law-legislation/texas/statutes/)
    * [Historical Texas Statutes](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/)
    * [Administrative Rules](/law-legislation/texas/administrative-rules/)
    * [Case Law](/law-legislation/texas/case-law/)
    * [Attorney General Opinions](/law-legislation/texas/attorney-general-opinions/)
    * [Municipal Ordinances](/law-legislation/texas/municipal-laws-and-ordinances/)
    * [Building Codes](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/)
  * [Federal Law & Legislation](/law-legislation/federal/)
    * [U.S. Constitution & Federal Statutes](/law-legislation/federal/constitution-statutes/)
    * [Federal Rules & Regulations](/law-legislation/federal/rules-and-regulations/)
  * [Laws of Other States](/law-legislation/laws-of-other-states/)

[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [texas](/law-legislation/texas/ "Texas") » constitution

Texas Constitution

The establishes the structure and purpose of the Texas government.

It is organized by articles. The first article sets out a bill of rights. The following articles establish the three branches of government: legislative, executive, and judicial.

The remaining articles cover many other topics such as:

  * suffrage;
  * public education;
  * taxation;
  * counties and municipalities;
  * public lands;
  * impeachment; and
  * other general provisions, including modes of amending the constitution.

History

The current constitution took effect on February 15, 1876. This current constitution is the seventh in Texas history. The previous six were the:

  * 1827 Constitution of the State of Coahuila and Tejas;
  * 1836 Constitution of the Republic of Texas; and
  * different versions of the constitution of Texas for the years 1845, 1861, 1866, and 1869.



Digital images of past constitutions are available through , a project of the and the University of Texas at Austin's School of Law.

Amendments

The legislature can propose amendments to the state constitution. Texas voters later decide whether to adopt the proposed amendments.

Since 1876, the legislature has proposed hundreds of amendments. The majority have been adopted by voters.

The Legislative Reference Library has a search. The Texas Legislative Council offers a .

Learn More

  * [Braden's Annotated Texas Constitution](/library-resources/collections/bradens-annotated-texas-constitution/ "Braden's Annotated Texas Constitution")
