[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [texas](/law-legislation/texas/ "Texas") » statutes

Statutes

The meets every two years on odd-numbered years. During the legislative session, hundreds of bills are introduced by legislators for consideration.

Bills that become law are arranged by subject matter into various codes such as the Election Code, Family Code, and Penal Code. These statutes are published by the Texas Legislative Council. They are also available in print from private publishers.

The legislature also meets when the Texas governor calls a special session. During a special session, the states that “there shall be no legislation upon subjects other than those” set forth in the governor's proclamation or otherwise presented to the legislature by the governor.

expand all collapse all

Current Texas Statutes 

The are available online.

While there is no official publisher of the Texas statutes, _Vernon's Texas Statutes and Codes Annotated_ is the most popular and widely accepted version. _Vernon's_ includes helpful annotations to case law, prior versions of the law, and other secondary sources.

Our library has print copies of _Vernon's_ , and it is also available at many [law libraries](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-texas/ "Law Libraries of Texas") across Texas.

To learn more, see from the Texas Legislative Council.

Historical Texas Statutes 

Our library's digitization efforts have brought online over 100 years of historical Texas statutes! We are proud to provide free public access to digitized copies of the Texas statutes from 1879 through 1984.

Years | Source  
---|---  
Before 1879 |  — Legislative Reference Library  
1879 – 1984 | [Historical Texas Statutes](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/ "Historical Texas Statutes") — State Law Library  
1985 – 2004 | Not online* — see note below  
2004 – present |  — Texas Legislature Online  
  
*There is no free, public source on the web for codified Texas statutes in effect between the last volume on our [historical Texas statutes page](http://www.sll.texas.gov/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/ "Historical Texas Statutes") and 2004. For these intervening years, the Legislative Reference Library's provides access to the session laws.

Our library has an extensive print collection of historical Texas statutes, and we make these available to the public during our [normal business hours](http://www.sll.texas.gov/about-us/about-the-library/#hours "About the Library"). If you cannot visit the library in person, [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian") for assistance.

[Texas Statutes (1879 – 1984)](/library-resources/collections/historical-texas-statutes/ "Historical Texas Statutes")

Bills and Session Laws 

Signed copies of bills Sessions | Years | Source  
---|---|---  
83rd – present | 2013 – present | Legislative Reference Library's   
78th – present | 2003 – present |  — University of North Texas, Portal to Texas History  
63rd – 79th | 1973 – 2005 | Legislative Reference Library's — digitization ongoing, see their for coverage  
1st – 62nd | 1846 – 1972 |  — includes bills from the Republic of Texas  
Session laws

After a regular legislative session, the general and special laws are published by the Texas Secretary of State. This collection is arranged by chapters.

Format | Source  
---|---  
Online | Legislative Reference Library's has digitized session laws going back to 1871 — digitization ongoing, see their for coverage  
Print | State Law Library has a from 1822 to present day  
  
Legislative History and Intent 

Researching the history of a law or why the legislature enacted a law involves looking at different sources. Each source helps inform the intent behind the legislation.

Many sources have been digitized and are available online. For older legislation, you may need to listen to audiotape recordings of committee hearings. For very old legislation, more advanced historical research techniques may be needed.

The from the Legislative Reference Library and the guide from the Tarlton Law Library explain which sources to use and link you to digitized materials.

Bill Files

Official documents concerning a bill from the legislative process are compiled into a bill file. Bill files may contain different versions of the bill, bill analyses, financial notes, committee reports, and amendments.

Sessions | Years | Source  
---|---|---  
71st – present | 1989 – present  
33rd – 79th | 1913 – 2005 |  from the Legislative Reference Library — see their page for current coverage  
1st – 62nd | 1846 – 1972  
Congress of the Republic of Texas | 1836 – 1845  
Bill History

A bill's history is a list of all the legislative actions that were taken on the bill and the date each action occurred. Additional information like a committee's name may also be listed.

This information is important because you can identify when the bill was discussed by a committee. Recordings or other records from the hearing can help you understand legislative intent.

Sessions | Years | Source  
---|---|---  
71st – present | 1989 – present  
63rd – 85th | 1973 – 2017 |  from the Legislative Reference Library — see their page for current coverage  
1st – 62nd | 1846 – 1972 | For any bill whose history is not already compiled, information may be found in the available on the Legislative Reference Library's website  
Committee Hearings and Floor Debates

Each chamber of the legislature has its own media office that handles audio and video recordings.

Senate Sessions | Years | Source  
---|---|---  
76th – present | 1999 – present  
62nd – 79th | 1972 – 2006 |  from the Texas State Library and Archives; see the for details  
House Sessions | Years | Source  
---|---|---  
77th – present | 2001 – present |  — includes both and   
57th & 63rd – 68th | 1962, 1973, 1975 – 1979, 1981 – 1984 |  from the Texas State Library and Archives — only certain proceedings available; see the for details  
Journals

Additional information may be found in the House and Senate Journals. See the collection from the Legislative Reference Library.

    * [ Law Libraries of Texas](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-texas/)
    * [ Law Libraries of Other States](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-other-states/)



[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [texas](/law-legislation/texas/ "Texas") » administrative rules

Administrative Rules

Administrative Code

The legislature authorizes agencies and commissions to create rules to help administer and carry out the law. The rules are compiled and organized by subject matter by the secretary of state as the . It is updated annually.

The online version of the code allows you to as it existed on a particular date going back to January 1, 1999.

The library has print copies of the Texas Administrative Code dating back to 1979. These are available for public viewing during our normal business hours. If you are unable to visit the library in person, [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) by phone or e-mail for assistance.

Texas Register

Changes to the Administrative Code are published in the , which serves as the journal of state agency rulemaking in Texas. The library has a of the Texas Register since it was first published.

The information published in the includes proposed, adopted, withdrawn and emergency rule actions; notices of state agency review of agency rules; governor's appointments; attorney general opinions; and miscellaneous documents such as requests for proposals.

of the Texas Register are on the secretary of state's website. at the Portal to Texas History from the University of North Texas.

Learn More

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:57 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [texas](/law-legislation/texas/ "Texas") » case law

Case Law

Texas uses a common-law system. In a common-law system, decisions from high courts are binding on lower courts. This concept is known as setting a precedent. Case law is derived from past decisions made by the courts. Because the courts are always hearing new cases and interpreting the law, case law is constantly evolving.

Researching case law involves reading court opinions. If you are not familiar with how to read a court opinion, see our .

To locate case law, you will need to use tools like or . These sources compile and categorize case law research to help make it accessible by topic or by keyword searching. You can also use footnotes or other annotations in secondary sources like a legal encyclopedia or a [legal practice guide](/library-resources/collections/digital-collection/?category=all) to locate case law on a topic.

Learn More

  * [About Texas Courts](/the-courts/about-the-texas-courts/ "About the Texas Courts")
  * [Texas Court Rules](/the-courts/texas-court-rules/ "Texas Court Rules")

[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [texas](/law-legislation/texas/ "Texas") » attorney general opinions

Attorney General Opinions

Upon request by , the Texas attorney general issues written interpretations of state law. These interpretations are known as .

While considered persuasive, they are not binding. Interpretation of state law is left to the courts.

Opinions do not address factual matters nor do they create or amend existing laws. Opinions can later be .

Current AG Opinions

Opinions from are online.

Pre-1939 AG Opinions

Prior to 1939, the publication of opinions was not systematic or comprehensive. See our [Attorney General Opinions (1891 – 1938)](/library-resources/collections/attorney-general-opinions-1891-1938/ "Attorney General Opinions \(1891–1938\)") page to learn more[.](/library-resources/collections/attorney-general-opinions-1891-1938/ "Attorney General Opinions \(1891–1938\)")

Letter Opinions

The attorney general previously issued “letter opinions.” While they carry the same force and effect as a formal opinion, letter opinions concerned non-controversial issues, issues that affected a particular group, or issues local in nature. As of January 4th, 1999, letter opinions are no longer issued. .

Open Records Decisions & Letter Rulings

The allows governmental bodies to request a decision from the attorney general regarding whether requested information may be withheld under one of the exceptions permitted by law. .

The attorney general also issues informal . Letter rulings are limited to the particular information at issue in each particular request and limited to the facts presented. Unless explicitly stated otherwise, letter rulings are not to be cited as precedent. .

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:57 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [texas](/law-legislation/texas/ "Texas") » municipal laws and ordinances

Municipal Ordinances

The outlines a municipality's authority to enact ordinances within its jurisdiction.

The code describes different types of municipalities like home rule and general law. Each type has specific procedures for enacting ordinances. Ordinances are usually enforced by local law enforcement agencies such as city police departments.

Counties also have some authority to enact ordinances, but a county's authority is generally more limited than that of a municipality. To access a county's ordinances, first check the county's official website. If not online, the county clerk, county judge, county commissioners, or your may provide access to county ordinances.

How to Locate Municipal Ordinances

Many municipalities publish their ordinances online, but not all do. If not online, you may need to go through the office of the city clerk or city secretary. In some small municipalities, you may need to contact the local councilpersons, mayor, aldermen, or city commissioners. Your may have a print copy of the ordinances.

The websites below are online collections for the codes and ordinances of many municipalities. If you do not find a municipality's ordinances on one site, check the others. Some municipalities may publish their ordinances on their own website rather than on a third-party site. [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) for assistance if you are having trouble locating ordinances.

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:57 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [texas](/law-legislation/texas/ "Texas") » building codes

Building Codes

Texas [statutes](/law-legislation/texas/statutes/ "Statutes"), [administrative rules](/law-legislation/texas/administrative-rules/ "Administrative Rules"), and [local ordinances](/law-legislation/municipal-laws-and-ordinances/ "Municipal Laws and Ordinances") occasionally adopt, incorporate, or refer to technical codes published by independent organizations.

These codes describe scientific and safety standards for structures and discuss specifications for construction practices, electrical systems, plumbing fixtures, fire safety, and many other topics.

Note The library cannot help determine which codes apply to your specific project.

Adopted by Reference

Even though they are incorporated as law, building codes are not reprinted within the law itself. Instead, they are “adopted by reference.” This means that the law will name the code and its publisher, but you must access the code itself elsewhere.

Where to Find Codes

We link to online editions on the publisher's website whenever possible. In addition, some local governments publish the codes and any local amendments on their website.

You may not always find the code online due to copyright restrictions from the publisher. If not online, check with your city clerk's office, a code enforcement or planning department, or a to view the code.

[ Residential Building Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/residential-building-codes/ "Residential Building Codes")

Construction, A/C, plumbing, energy efficiency, pools and spas, and manufactured housing.

[ Non-Residential Building Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/non-residential-building-codes/ "Non-Residential Building Codes")

Commercial buildings, energy efficiency, swimming pools, modular buildings, schools, hospitals, medical care facilities, jails.

[ Electrical Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/electrical-codes/ "Electrical Codes")

State electrical code for all municipal and commercial buildings.

[ Fire Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/fire-codes/ "Fire Codes")

Fire code for all safety inspections and fire codes in certain counties.

[ Gas and Fuel Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/gas-and-fuel-codes/ "Gas and Fuel Codes")

Plumbing, retail service stations, modular buildings, LP-gas.

[ Life Safety Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/life-safety-codes/ "Life Safety Codes")

Assisted living, nursing, and other care facilities.

[ Mechanical Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/mechanical-codes/ "Mechanical Codes")

HVAC and refrigeration systems.

[ Plumbing Codes ](/law-legislation/texas/building-codes/plumbing-codes/ "Plumbing Codes")

State plumbing codes.

_Disclaimer_ : Our listing of adopted codes is not comprehensive. We have attempted to include the most common adopted codes. State laws quoted on this page are not the official versions of the law. See the website.

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:57 PM

Federal Law & Legislation

For an explanation of how federal laws are enacted, see from the .

During its sessions, the United States Congress considers hundreds of . Bills that become law are compiled and published in a bound volume of the . Every six years, all federal legislation currently in effect is compiled and arranged by subject matter in the .

Learn more at the links below.

  * [U.S. Constitution & Federal Statutes](/law-legislation/federal/constitution-statutes/)
  * [Federal Rules & Regulations](/law-legislation/federal/rules-and-regulations/)

U.S. Constitution & Federal Statutes

U.S. Constitution

The establishes the government of the United States.

It was signed on September 17, 1787. After it was ratified, it went into effect on March 4, 1789.

U.S. Code

Federal statutes are organized by subject matter in the .

Often, federal laws are given or referred to by common names such as the "Civil Rights Act of 1968," the "USA PATRIOT Act," or the "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act." The Cornell Legal Information Institute offers a listing of federal laws by their .

Statutes

Before laws are added to the , there are a handful of steps that must be taken.

After a bill becomes law:

  1. The bill is forwarded to the for filing and publication. The Archivist assigns a public or private law number, depending on the type of legislation.
  2. The bill is officially printed as an individual pamphlet commonly known as a "slip law."
  3. Once a congressional session ends, its legislation is compiled and published chronologically as a bound volume of the .



The statutes are periodically reorganized by subject matter. This arrangement is called the .

To learn more, see from the .

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:57 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [law & legislation](/law-legislation/ "Law & Legislation") » [federal](/law-legislation/federal/ "Federal") » rules and regulations

Federal Rules & Regulations

Code of Federal Regulations

Statutes from the U.S. Congress give federal agencies the authority to create rules. These rules help in the administration and implementation of federal laws. Rules are arranged by subject matter and published as the .

Federal Register

Before changes can be made to the , the federal agency proposing a change must publish an announcement in the . The serves as the daily journal of the federal government.

You can access editions of the Federal Register going back to 1994 at its . Older editions are available through the .

Laws of Other States

The laws of all 50 states are available online. Contact a [law library](/legal-help/find-legal-information/law-libraries-of-other-states/ "Law Libraries of Other States") if you have questions about other states' laws.

Southwest Southeast

West

Midwest

Northeast

[home](/ "Home") » [the courts](/the-courts/ "The Courts") » about the texas courts

About the Texas Courts

Each court in the has a specific jurisdiction. Our court system is made up of:

  * municipal courts;
  * justice courts (justice of the peace);
  * county courts;
  * district courts; and
  * .



At the highest level, the hears civil cases and the hears criminal cases.

For information on court proceedings and procedural rules, see the [Texas court rules](/the-courts/texas-court-rules/ "Texas Court Rules") page.

Obtaining Court Records

Court records are made available through the court clerk's office. Contact the court clerk for information on how to obtain copies. 

For help understanding where to locate records, see the library's  guide.

Document Delivery Service

Our library facilitates access to court records filed in the following courts: 

  * (criminal cases only).



Through our fee-based [Document Delivery Service](/about-us/public-services/document-delivery/ "Document Delivery"), we provide copies of available court records at a cost of $0.25 per page plus other fees. This service is also available for inmates in TDCJ facilities through our [Inmate Copy Service](/about-us/public-services/inmate-copy-service/ "Inmate Copy Service").

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:57 PM

[home](/ "Home") » [the courts](/the-courts/ "The Courts") » texas court rules

Texas Court Rules

Court proceedings in Texas follow the rules and standards set forth by the Texas Supreme Court. Access Texas online.[](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian")

[Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian") for help if you have questions about locating or accessing Texas court rules.

Court Proceedings

The govern the proceedings in civil trials.

The governs criminal proceedings.

When a case is appealed, the govern the appeals process.

Evidence

The govern the admissibility and use of evidence in most court proceedings.

Local Court Rules

At a local level, lower courts often adopt local rules for court proceedings in their jurisdictions. Local rules are .

You may also find local rules on your county's or city's website. If not online, contact the district clerk, county clerk, or city clerk for help accessing local rules.

Ethics and Conduct

The is the set of ethics rules for judges in Texas. The accepts and investigates complaints against Texas judges.

Attorneys are bound by the and the . Ethical complaints and reports of misconduct are investigated by the .

Administration

The set out certain responsibilities for judges, public access to judicial records, and other administrative matters. You can find more administrative rules and standards on the .

Parental Notification

The Texas Supreme Court adopted that govern proceedings for obtaining a court order authorizing a minor to consent to an abortion without notice to, or the consent of, a parent, managing conservator, or guardian. These rules were adopted in accordance with .

[home](/ "Home") » [the courts](/the-courts/ "The Courts") » about the federal courts

About the Federal Courts

The federal courts system is divided into 94 separate judicial districts. All 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico each have at least one federal judicial district.

These 94 judicial districts are organized into 12 separate regional circuits. Each circuit has one federal court of appeals.

The highest court in the U.S. federal court system is the . The Supreme Court, at its discretion and within certain guidelines, hears a limited amount of cases during each of its terms.

Courts of Special Jurisdiction

Federal courts of special jurisdiction include:

  * ;
  * the ;
  * the ; and
  * the .



To learn more, see .

Obtaining Court Records

In general, court records are made public through the office of the court clerk.

For help understanding how to access federal court records, see the library's guide.

Options include:

  * for case and docket information; and
  * checking the for published opinions.

[home](/ "Home") » [the courts](/the-courts/ "The Courts") » federal court rules

Federal Court Rules

In the federal court system, the serves as the policy-making body. The rules and policies set forth by the Judicial Conference govern the administration of the federal courts.

Court Proceedings

The govern federal court proceedings. You can find online.

Federal civil trials are governed by the Federal criminal trials are governed by the . Cases heard in a federal court of appeal are governed by the .

For the rules that govern other federal proceedings, the includes:

  * (habeas corpus petitions)

Local Rules

At their own discretion and within certain guidelines, federal trial courts and federal courts of appeal can adopt their own local rules. requires that federal courts publish any local rules on their website.

Ethics and Conduct

There are various . Federal judges are subject to the . There is a separate .

If you are seeking information on how to file a complaint of judicial misconduct or judicial disability, see the U.S. Courts page on the .

  1. [Texas State Law Library](https://www.sll.texas.gov)
  2. Legal Aid



Search

Legal Help

Need free or low-cost legal help? Our list of legal hotlines, clinics, aid organizations, and other resources can help you find assistance.

**Disclaimer:** **The State Law Library cannot tell you what a law means for your situation.**

**Ask a Librarian**

  * [Ask a Librarian](https://www.sll.texas.gov/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian")
  * [Law Libraries of Texas](https://www.sll.texas.gov/self-help/where-to-go-for-help/law-libraries-of-texas/ "Law Libraries of Texas")



**Contact an Attorney**

  * [Legal Help & Information](https://www.sll.texas.gov/legal-help/ "Legal Help & Information")



Legal Aid

These organizations provide general legal advice and representation and host legal clinics for free or for a low cost to those who qualify. 

If you instead need to hire a lawyer and aren't sure how to find one, visit our page for listings of lawyer referral services, legal directories, and bar associations.

**[Referrals& Directories](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299041) **|[ ](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299044)**[For All Texas Residents](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299044)** | **[East& Southeast Texas](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299043)**[ ](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299043)|**[ West, Southwest & Central Texas](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299042)**[ ](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299042)|**[ North & Northeast Texas](#s-lg-box-wrapper-38299045)**

Referrals & Directories

  * This directory is published by the , the state's principal bar association. It contains contact information for many legal aid organizations that are available across Texas. In addition, the Texas Bar has written and collected .

  * This is a listing of all the legal services providers in Texas. Service providers are listed by name as well as by service area. It also provides information about Legal Aid and has an online form for finding legal assistance.




For All Texas Residents

  * The Texas Legal Services Center is a legal nonprofit that provides free representation and assistance to rural Texans who qualify for their services based on income or other criteria. They also sponsor various projects that assist low-income and disadvantaged Texans who need legal help.




East & Southeast Texas

  * HVLP provides pro bono legal services to low-income residents of Harris County.

  * Lone Star Legal Aid provides civil legal services to low-income clients in the Houston and east Texas area. They serve 72 counties in east, southeast, and northeast Texas as well as 4 counties in southwest Arkansas. See their website for a description of the types of cases they handle.

  * The Earl Carl Institute for Legal & Social Policy, Inc. at Texas Southern University's Law School provides free legal aid services to low-income people. See their website for specific topics covered and qualifying details.




West, Southwest, & Central Texas

  * TRLA provides free civil legal services to the indigent residents of central, south, and west Texas as well as migrant and seasonal farmworkers throughout Texas, Alabama, Arkansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Tennessee. View their website for a list of Texas counties in TRLA's service area.

  * This nonprofit serves low-income residents in central Texas and helps to provide access to the civil legal system.

  * Austin Community Law Center is a nonprofit organization that offers legal services at sliding-scale fees. Lawyers can assist with both civil and certain criminal legal issues. ACLC also offers unbundled legal services ("law a la carte"). Open to clients throughout Texas.

  * The Austin Tenants Council provides telephone counseling, mediation services, in-house counseling, housing discrimination assistance, and lease forms. Please note that eligibility for some of these services is limited to Travis County residents who meet certain income requirements. Their website has resources that are helpful to all Texans looking for information on landlord/tenant law.

  * The Lubbock Legal Aid Society provides legal assistance to low-income residents in and around Lubbock.




North & Northwest Texas

  * The Dallas Volunteer Attorney Program offers free legal assistance to residents of the Dallas area who meet their qualifications. They also host several legal advice clinics throughout the Dallas area on certain days of the month.

  * Legal Aid of NorthWest Texas provides civil legal services to low-income Texas residents within their . You can call their Legal Aid Line to apply for legal services at or apply for assistance through their .




  * Last Updated: Nov 7, 2024 2:40 PM
  * URL: https://guides.sll.texas.gov/legal-help



[Report a problem](https://www.sll.texas.gov/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/)

For Attorneys

The following pages are aimed at Texas attorneys and other members of the judiciary.

  * [Bar Association Newsletters](/for-attorneys/bar-association-newsletters/)
  * [CLE Materials](/library-resources/collections/continuing-legal-education-materials/)
  * [Document Delivery](/about-us/public-services/document-delivery/)
  * [Law Practice Management](/library-resources/collections/law-practice-management/)
  * [Law Reviews](/library-resources/collections/law-reviews/)
  * [Recommended Titles and Treatises](/library-resources/collections/recommended-titles-and-treatises/)
  * [Lexis Training](/about-us/public-services/lexis-training/)

[home](/ "Home") » [for attorneys](/for-attorneys/ "For Attorneys") » bar association newsletters

Bar Association Newsletters

Many of the various publish newsletters, bulletins, and journals to help keep the local legal communities current on issues that may be of interest to them. Below we provide links to local bar association newsletters that we have found to be available freely online.

Please [contact us](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) if you find any errors or omissions on this page so that we can keep this list current.

page last updated: 19 Jul 2023 5:00 PM

Legal Help & Info

Legal Help

Hire a lawyer, get basic legal advice, or find free or low-cost legal assistance.

Legal Info

Find [e-books and databases](/library-resources/collections/digital-collection) that can help you accomplish a legal task, understand the law, or represent yourself in court.

[ Legal FAQs ](/faqs/ "FAQs")

[ Law Libraries of Texas](/self-help/where-to-go-for-help/law-libraries-of-texas/)

[ Law Libraries of Other States](/self-help/where-to-go-for-help/law-libraries-of-other-states/)

page last updated: 23 Sep 2024 5:58 PM

Legal Help & Info

Legal Help

Hire a lawyer, get basic legal advice, or find free or low-cost legal assistance.

Legal Info

Find [e-books and databases](/library-resources/collections/digital-collection) that can help you accomplish a legal task, understand the law, or represent yourself in court.

[home](/ "Home") » legal help

Legal Help & Info

Legal Help

Hire a lawyer, get basic legal advice, or find free or low-cost legal assistance.

Legal Info

Find [e-books and databases](/library-resources/collections/digital-collection) that can help you accomplish a legal task, understand the law, or represent yourself in court.

[ Legal FAQs ](/faqs/ "FAQs")

[ Law Libraries of Texas](/self-help/where-to-go-for-help/law-libraries-of-texas/)

[ Law Libraries of Other States](/self-help/where-to-go-for-help/law-libraries-of-other-states/)

[home](/ "Home") » faqs

Legal FAQs

Answers to frequently asked legal questions.

Search 

Popular

  * [Is abortion illegal in Texas?](/faqs/abortion-illegal-texas/)
  * [Can a person convicted of a felony vote in Texas?](/faqs/felony-conviction-vote/)
  * [How can I sell my gun to another person?](/faqs/private-gun-sales/)
  * [Who can perform a marriage ceremony in Texas?](/faqs/perform-marriage-ceremony/)



New & Recently Updated

  * [What is a Lady Bird deed?](/faqs/what-is-a-lady-bird-deed/)
  * [Can my landlord enter my rental property without permission?](/faqs/landlord-entry/)
  * [My landlord sold the property. Can the new owner kick me out or change the lease?](/faqs/landlord-tenant-property-sale/)
  * [Can I remove an eviction from my record?](/faqs/eviction-record-removal/)



By Topic

expand all collapse all

Abortion 

  * [Where can I find Texas laws on abortion?](/faqs/texas-abortion-laws/)
  * [Is abortion illegal in Texas?](/faqs/abortion-illegal-texas/)
  * [Does Texas have trigger laws related to abortion?](/faqs/texas-trigger-law/)
  * [What does Senate Bill 8 say about abortions?](/faqs/abortion-senate-bill-8/)



Child Custody & Support 

  * [What is the process for stepparent adoption?](/faqs/stepparent-adoption/)
  * [Do grandparents have a legal right to see their grandchildren?](/faqs/grandparents-rights/)
  * [How can I modify my child custody or support order?](/faqs/modify-child-custody-or-support-order/)
  * [Can I terminate my parental rights?](/faqs/terminate-parental-rights/)



Consumer Protection 

Business Practices

  * [What is the maximum fee for a bounced check?](/faqs/bounced-check-fee/)
  * [Do I have to provide my Social Security number (SSN) to a business?](/faqs/provide-ssn-to-business/)
  * [Can gift cards expire?](/faqs/can-gift-cards-expire/)
  * [What does the law say about refunds and returns in Texas?](/faqs/refunds-returns/)
  * [How late can telemarketers call?](/faqs/how-late-can-telemarketers-call/)
  * [Can businesses raise their prices during disasters?](/faqs/disaster-price-gouging/)
  * [Can a business charge a fee for using a credit card?](/faqs/credit-card-surcharge/)

Contracts
  * [Are auto-renewing contracts legal in Texas?](/faqs/auto-renewing-contracts/)
  * [Do I have 3 days to cancel a contract in Texas?](/faqs/three-days-cancel-contract/)

Debt & Credit
  * [Debt collectors keep calling me. What can I do?](/faqs/debt-collector-calls/)
  * [What is the maximum interest rate under Texas law?](/faqs/maximum-interest-rate/)
  * [How long can negative information appear on my credit report?](/faqs/negative-info-credit-report/)
  * [Can debt collectors call my work or family?](/faqs/debt-collectors-call-work-family/)
  * [What is the statute of limitations on debt?](/faqs/debt-statute-of-limitations/)

Vehicle Sales
  * [I bought a used car, but it does not run well. What can I do?](/faqs/dtpa-used-car/)
  * [I just bought a car and decided I don't want it. Do I have a legal right to return it?](/faqs/return-car-after-purchase/)
  * [Is there a lemon law in Texas?](/faqs/texas-lemon-law/)



COVID-19 

  * [Can my landlord raise my rent?](/faqs/rent-increase/)
  * [Are there any COVID-19 requirements for people traveling to Texas?](/faqs/covid-19-travel/)
  * [Can I carry a gun without a license during a disaster?](/faqs/carry-gun-during-disaster/)
  * [How can I report violations of mask orders?](/faqs/report-mask-order-violations/)
  * [Can I be required to show proof of a COVID-19 test?](/faqs/covid-19-test-proof/)

Masks
  * [Does Texas have an anti-mask law?](/faqs/anti-mask-law/)
  * [Can I carry a gun while wearing a mask?](/faqs/carry-gun-mask/)
  * [Can a business require me to wear a mask?](/faqs/business-mask-policy/)
  * [Do I have to wear a mask if I have a disability?](/faqs/mask-disability-accommodation/)

Vaccines
  * [Can I be required to get a COVID-19 vaccine?](/faqs/covid-19-vaccine-mandates/)
  * [Can I be required to show a COVID-19 “vaccine passport?”](/faqs/covid-19-vaccine-passports/)



Criminal Offenses 

  * [Where can I find Texas laws on abortion?](/faqs/texas-abortion-laws/)

Contact an Attorney

**Disclaimer:** The State Law Library cannot tell you what a law means for your situation. Please [contact an attorney](https://www.sll.texas.gov/legal-help/) for help determining what the law means for you. If you have questions or need help finding resources, please [ask a librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian").

Law Libraries of Texas

Most county and university law libraries listed here are open to the public, but some may have restrictions. Contact a library directly for details. We are not affiliated with any library listed.

If you do not find a law library near you, try a .

1201 Huey Road, 1st FloorBelton, Texas 76513

see details

**Note:** Library is open to the public, but no reference services are available

100 Dolorosa, 5th Floor San Antonio, Texas 78205

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes, limited to 30 minutes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Texas Jurisprudence_ , _Texas Practice Series_ , _Federal Reporter_ , _Federal Supplement_

1 Camino Santa Maria San Antonio, Texas 78228

see details

St. Mary's University is a private university with a law school and a law library. Please contact the library directly for details about access to the public.

111 E. Locust, Suite 315A Angleton, Texas 77515

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Texas Jurisprudence_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , _Texas Cases_ , _Texas Digest_ , and federal treatises

974 E. Harrison StreetBrownsville, Texas 78520

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, general internet access

**Print resources available:** Mostly Texas materials – highlights include Matthew Bender publications

2100 Bloomdale Road, Suite 10216McKinney, Texas 75071 ext. 4255

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, access limited to 30 minutes when other patrons are waiting

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw Classic, WestlawNext, Matthew Bender Online

**Print resources available:** Comprehensive collection of Texas and federal legal materials

199 Main Plaza, Ste. B102 New Braunfels, Texas 78130

see details

**Library hours:** hours vary — see the library website

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** Lexis Advance and various legal/government research websites

**Print resources available:** Mostly Texas materials

600 Commerce Street, Suite 760Dallas, Texas 75202

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, limited to 1 hour per person per day

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw and LexisNexis, LexisNexis Digital Library

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Print resources available:** A comprehensive collection of Texas materials and some federal materials – highlights include O'Connor's titles, Texas Bar manuals, and the  _United States Code Annotated_

**(not open to the public, only to students, faculty, staff, and bar members)** 1901 Main StreetDallas, Texas 75201

see details

**Note:** The library is not open to the public, only to students, faculty, staff, and bar members.

6550 Hillcrest AvenueDallas, Texas 75275

see details

Southern Methodist University is a private university with a law school and a law library. Please contact the library directly for details about access to the public.

121 N Woodrow Lane, Suite 160Denton, Texas 76205-4524 (Local) (Metro)

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes, 9 computers

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** Mostly Texas materials – highlights include _Texas Jurisprudence_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , O'Connor's titles

300 North Grant, Room 316 Odessa, Texas 79763

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes, 2 computers, time limits placed according to need

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** Mostly Texas materials – highlights include _Texas Probate Forms and Procedures_ , _Texas Practice Guide_ , federal statutes

109 S. Jackson Street 2nd Floor Waxahachie, Texas 75165

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes, 2 computers

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** WestlawNext

**Print resources available:** Mostly Texas materials – highlights include _Texas Cases_ , _Vernon's Texas Statutes Annotated_ , O'Connor's titles, _Texas Practice Guide_ , and _United States Code Annotated_

500 E. San Antonio, Suite 1202 El Paso, Texas 79901

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw Classic and WestlawNext

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Federal Reporter_ , _Texas Jurisprudence_ , Shepard's titles (Texas and U.S.), _Texas Digest_ , _S.W. Reporter_ , _Vernon's Texas Statutes Annotated_ , and _National Law Review_

**Note:** Library no longer updates the regional reporters; the older volumes are maintained on the shelf

_Inside the Fort Bend County Justice Center_ 1422 Eugene Heimann CircleRm 20714Richmond, Texas 77469

see details

**Mailing Address:** 301 Jackson Street, Richmond, Texas 77469

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, Lexis Advance, O'Connor's Online, HeinOnline, State Bar practice manuals, James Publishing forms

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include U.S. Supreme Court cases, _United States Code Annotated_ , _Texas Practice Guide_ , _Texas Cases_

**Note:** Many print resources are also available electronically

600 59th Street, Suite 1600 Galveston, Texas 77551

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** Yes

**Note:** The library is open to the public, but no reference services are available

100 W. Houston, Suite 27 Sherman, Texas 75090-7167

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. 

**Public computer access:** No

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw Classic, WestlawNext, NetLibrary

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Texas Practice Guide_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , Texas and federal forms for civil, criminal, family, and bankruptcy law

**Note:** Please contact Tera Norris at the County Judge's office for further assistance. Many print resources available on CD-ROMs, including _Texas Jury Pattern Charges_ , _DUI Handbook_ , _Texas Probate System_

101 E. Methvin, Suite 202Longview, Texas 75601

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw Classic, LexisNexis; database access limited to mostly Texas law

**Print resources available:** Mostly Texas materials – highlights include _Vernon's Texas Statutes Annotated_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , and _Texas Transaction Guide_

1019 Congress Street, 1st Floor Houston, Texas 77002-1799

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, 25 computers

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** WestlawNext, LexisNexis, Hein Online, RIA Checkpoint (tax database), CCH IntelliConnect

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include O'Connor's titles, Matthew Bender treatises, _United States Code Annotated_ , State Bar of Texas CLE course handbooks and practice manuals

**Note:** may have volunteers in the library available for assistance. Please contact the library directly for more details.

1303 San Jacinto Street Houston, Texas 77002

see details

The South Texas College of Law Houston is a private law school with a law library. Please contact the library directly for details about access to the public.

4604 Calhoun Road, Room 100 Houston, Texas 77204

see details

Please contact the O'Quinn Law Library at the University of Houston Law Center directly for details about access to the public.

3100 Cleburne Street Houston, Texas 77004

see details

Please contact the Thurgood Marshall School of Law Library at Texas Southern University directly for details about access to the public.

712 S. Stagecoach Trail, Suite 2026San Marcos, Texas 78666

see details

**Library hours:** Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. and Thursday from 1:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** WestlawNext, _Texas Litigation Guide_ , and _Texas Transaction Guide_

**Print resources available:** Collection is Texas specific – highlights include _Vernon's Texas Statutes Annotated_ , _Texas Cases_ , _Texas Jurisprudence_ , O'Connor's titles

**Note:** The collection of print materials is decreasing in favor of electronic publications

100 N. Closner BoulevardEdinburg, Texas 78539

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, 6 computers

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, ProDocs

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _S.W. Reporter_ , _Texas Cases_ , _United States Code Annotated and Forms_ , _United States Statutes at Large_

**Note:** Library has a dedicated self-help workstation for _pro se_ litigants

204 S. Buffalo Avenue, Room 108 Cleburne, Texas 76033

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** The collection is mostly Texas materials with just a few federal print resources

100 W. Mulberry Street 2nd Floor Kaufman, Texas 75142 ext. 1356

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, no restriction on time unless there are others waiting

**Books available for checkout:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _S.W. Reporter_ , _Texas Cases_ , _United States Code Service Forms and Advanced Sheets_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , _Texas Transaction Guide_

**Liberty County Law Library**

**(not open to the public, only bar members)** 1915 Trinity Street Liberty, Texas 77575

see details

**Note:** The library is not open to the public, only bar members

916 Main Street, Suite 306 Lubbock, Texas 79401

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. (closed for lunch from 1:00 p.m. to 1:30 p.m.)

**Public computer access:** Yes, 2 computers are available to the public, but internet access is limited to 4 websites from/about TexasLawHelp.org, Servicemembers Civil Relief Act, Texas Young Lawyers Association, and the Texas Judicial Branch

**Books available for checkout:** Yes, but only judges and attorneys can borrow books

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw (for attorneys and the public) and LexisNexis (librarian access only)

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include Matthew Bender publications, _Texas Cases_ , Texas State Bar publications (practice manuals, forms, probate), _United States Code Annotated Forms_ , _Federal Practice Guide_ , _American Jurisprudence_

1802 Hartford Avenue Lubbock, Texas 79415

see details

Please contact the Texas Tech School of Law Library directly for details about public access.

501 Washington Avenue Waco, Texas 76701

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, only for legal research and searching for previous cases

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis

**Note:** No librarian or reference services are available

1114 South University Parks Drive Waco, Texas 76706

see details

Baylor University is a private university with a law school and a law library. Please contact the library directly for details about public access.

500 N. Loraine Street Suite 100 Midland, Texas 79701

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, restricted to legal research and document drafting only

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Texas Jurisprudence_ , _Texas Cases_ , _Texas Statutes_ , _Texas Transaction Guide_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , _Texas Family Practice Manual_ , _United States Code Annotated Forms_

301 North Thompson, Suite 105 Conroe, Texas 77301

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes, but library computers are strictly for legal research only

**Books available for checkout:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis Advanced, Westlaw, Hein Online, Knowles publications

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Texas Transaction Guide_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , _Texas Family Practice Manual_ , Matthew Bender publications, _Texas Jurisprudence_ , _American Law Reports_ , _United States Code Annotated_

**Note:** A reference attorney may be available for assistance. Please contact the library directly for more details.

901 Leopard Street, Room 601 Corpus Christi, Texas 78401

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes, includes a workstation for self-represented litigants

**Books available for checkout:** Yes, but only by legal professionals

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, TexasLawHelp.org, TexShare's Gale Legal Forms, Legal Information and Reference Center

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Federal Reporter_ , O'Connor's titles, _Southwestern Reporter_ , _Texas Cases_ , _Texas Practice Guide_ , _Vernon's Texas Codes and Statutes Annotated_ , and more. Please see the library's website for details.

**Note:** The library is an eviction Zoom hearing site for those without digital access to virtually meet with a judge.

1111 East Yellowjacket Lane Rockwall, Texas 75087

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Vernon's Texas Statutes Annotated_ , Matthew Bender publications, _Texas Cases_ , _Federal Cases_ , _Supreme Court Reports_

100 North Broadway Tyler, Texas 75702

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis and Westlaw

100 W. Weatherford, 4th floor Fort Worth, Texas 76196

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes, library computers are intended for legal research only

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis, Westlaw Classic, WestlawNext, HeinOnline

**Print resources available:** Please see the library catalog on the library's website

1515 Commerce Street Fort Worth, Texas 76102

see details

Please contact the Dee J. Kelly Law Library at Texas A&M University's School of Law directly for details about access to the public.

300 Oak Street, Suite 301Abilene, Texas 79602

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes, library computers are intended for legal research only. Computer access is restricted to 20 minutes, per person, per day.

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Texas Jurisprudence_ , _Texas Transaction Guide_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , _Texas Family Practice Manual_ , _United States Code_ , _American Law Reports_

1700 Guadalupe, 2nd FloorAustin, Texas 78701

see details

**Note:** Please see the library's website for details about their services. A reference attorney may be available for assistance.

727 East Dean Keeton Street Austin, Texas 78705

see details

Please contact the Tarlton Law Library at the University of Texas at Austin's School of Law for details about access to the public.

**[Travis County: Texas State Law Library](https://www.sll.texas.gov "Travis County: Texas State Law Library")**

Tom C. Clark Building 205 West 14th Street Austin, Texas 78701 (toll-free in Texas) 

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** Westlaw, LexisNexis, HeinOnline, and hundreds of legal e-books

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Vernon's Texas Statutes Annotated_ , O'Connor's titles, _Texas Litigation Guide_ , Matthew Bender/Dorsaneo practice guides, _Texas Jurisprudence_ , _American Jurisprudence_ , _S.W. Reporter_ , _Federal Reporter_

1110 Victoria Street, Suite 105 Laredo, Texas 78040

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** Yes

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Vernon's Texas Statutes Annotated_ , O'Connor's titles, Texas Bar journals, _Texas Transaction Guide_ , _Texas Litigation Guide_ , _S.W. Reporter_ , _Federal Reporter_

900 7th Street, Room 305 Wichita Falls, Texas 76301

see details

**Library hours:** M-F, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m

**Public computer access:** Yes

**Books available for checkout:** No

**Electronic resources available:** LexisNexis, Westlaw, LGS

**Print resources available:** Texas and federal materials – highlights include _Texas Motions Practice_ , O'Connor's titles

Law Libraries of Other States

While some are state law libraries, other law libraries are supreme court libraries or divisions within the state's library and archives. The Minnesota State Law Library also offers a .

Southwest Southeast

  * Georgia Law Library — not available to the public



West

Midwest

Northeast

page last updated: 18 Oct 2024 11:28 AM

The library building will be closed on Friday, November 15th for staff training. Librarians will be available by [phone and email](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/) until 11:00 a.m. that day. We will reopen with [regular library hours](/about-us/about-the-library/#hours) on Monday, November 18th at 8:00 a.m. 

The library will be closed on Monday, November 11th, for Veterans Day. We will reopen with [regular library hours](/about-us/about-the-library/#hours) at 8:00 a.m. on Tuesday, November 12th. 

Quick Links

Library Spotlight 

Feature [**National Estate Planning Awareness Week**](/spotlight/2024/10/national-estate-planning-awareness-week/)

October 23, 2024

October 21 – 27 is National Estate Planning Awareness Week! Estate planning may sound spooky and mysterious, but it doesn't have to be. We're here to help.

An estate plan is a set of formal instructions for when a person dies or can no longer make decisions. If there is no plan, matters are typically decided based on existing laws. The consequences can be frightful when your preferences aren’t taken into account.

[Read more ](/spotlight/2024/10/national-estate-planning-awareness-week/)

Feature [**National Voter Registration Day**](/spotlight/2024/09/national-voter-registration-day/)

September 13, 2024

Tuesday, September 17th is ! This civic holiday is the largest single-day voter registration drive. It’s a great day to register to vote or update your registration status.

[Read more ](/spotlight/2024/09/national-voter-registration-day/)

[ See more posts ](/spotlight/)

About Us 

We are a public law library.

We serve the legal research needs of the , the , the , other state agencies and commissions, and the citizens of the state.

Learn more [about the library](/about-us/about-the-library/ "About the Library").

Location & Hours

Open to the public Monday through Friday8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. ()

Tom C. Clark BuildingRoom G01 (ground floor)Austin, TX 78701

Questions? [Ask a Librarian](/about-us/public-services/ask-a-librarian/ "Ask a Librarian").

**How are we doing? !**

[home](/ "Home") » [about us](/about-us/ "About Us") » [library policies](/about-us/library-policies/ "Library Policies") » accessibility policy

Accessibility Policy

The State Law Library website exists in a form that is accessible to a broad range of access devices. We strive to meet the recommendations set forth by the (W3C) in their (WCAG). This website meets the definition of a generally accessible Internet site as defined in .

To help us meet web accessibility standards and to ensure that we comply with state and federal law, our website is manually reviewed for compliance with the and . We also review any new or modified web pages or web designs for compliance. In conjunction with our manual reviews, we verify the accessibility of our site with the and the , which are .

If you are unable to access any portion of our website, please do not hesitate to contact us. Reasonable efforts will be made by the library in order to accommodate patrons who use standards-compliant web browsers. The library is open to suggestions on how the accessibility of this website can be improved. Please [contact us](/about-us/contact-us/ "Contact Us") to reach our accessibility coordinator.

Accessibility of Library Databases

The library offers access to various third-party . We do not have any control over the appearance, usability, or accessibility of these databases, but we are happy to provide reasonable accommodations to a library patron with a disability. Please [contact us](/about-us/contact-us/ "Contact Us") to request assistance.

Several of the third parties have their own accessibility policies or tips and may also be able to assist you if their website is not accessible. Below are links to some of these accessibility policies.

  * and

{'title': 'Accessibility Policy', 'description': 'The library aims to make our website accessible to those with disabilities. Our accessibility policy describes how we monitor for compliance with Section 508.', 'keywords': 'accessibility, section 508, accommodations for disabilities, accessibility coordinator, accessibility compliance', 'author': 'AL'}
